subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 12th July 2019: Stocks climb to fresh record highs (again)
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, dollar down, crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Fed’s Evans and Kashkari calls for rate cuts; strong US PPI; China trade data disappoints, points to slowing economy;
  • COMING UP: SUN: Chinese GDP, Retail Sales and Industrial Production, MON: Swedish Unemployment, US NY Empire State Manufacturing, NZ CPI, TUE: RBA minutes, UK Labour Market Report, German ZEW, US Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Business Inventories, WED: UK CPI, EZ CPI, US Housing Starts and Building Permits, THU: Australian Labour Market Report, UK Retail Sales, Philadelphia Fed Manufacturing Index, FRI: Japanese National CPI, German PPI, UK PSNB, Canadian Retail Sales, Uni. Of Michigan. Click here to read our full week ahead preview; our weekly central bank briefing can be accessed here.

 

* TRUMP: US President Trump made a set of wide-ranging comments, covering everything from China to fake news. Overnight, he stoked trade tensions with china, stating that China was not living up to its commitments to buy agricultural products from the US. Later, he took to Twitter to task once again accuses China of devaluing its currency, and subsidizing its companies to lessen effect of tariffs. He again repeated that the biggest parts of Mexico and China trade deals has not yet been revealed. Trump also repeated claims that other countries have been ripping the US off for years, and tariffs were a great negotiating tool, as well as a great revenue producer, and were having little effect on consumers.

* FED: Overnight, Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said downside risks and soft inflation argue for easing monetary policy, while she added that judgement on appropriate path of rates will depend on evolution of data and risks. Furthermore, Brainard said the economy is expanding solidly and financials markets are supportive of growth, but also noted capital spending is lacklustre and business sentiment is soft. Also, overnight, Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated that he supports a rate cut to re-anchor inflation expectations, while he suggested that a 25bps cut would not be enough of a shock and that 50bps cut is needed. Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said that the fact that inflation is low is a victory, not a defeat, before adding consumer spending is incredibly strong. Fed's Evans (Voter) said that does not see the timing of a rate cut as critical, but he sees a 50bps rate reduction as appropriate by the end of the year, and added that current rates may be more restrictive than they actually should be. Evans also mentioned that slowing foreign growth is going to dampen the US economy and a risk management approach means being a little more accommodative in case downside risks materialise but we 'don't want to go too far'.

* US JUNE PPI: As with the CPI report, there was an upside surprise with the PPI report. Pantheon Macroeconomics said it was hard to worry about PPI inflation: "Goods inflation is slowing sharply, and the trend in the Y/Y rate for services ex-trade services has hovered around 2.5% for the past year," adding that "the inflation threat right now is CPI pass-through from tariffs and rising labour costs in low-productivity services sectors."

* CHINA TRADE DATA: Exports were hit, turning negative in June, as the US ramped up tariffs on China in May, against the backdrop of cooling global demand. Imports were also softer, amid a renewed domestic slowdown. Capital Economics said the export data was negative partly due to a stronger base for comparison, but it also notes that shipments fell in seasonally adjusted M/M terms. "The latest US tariff hike, implemented in the middle of May, probably contributed to this drop, alongside a broader slowdown in foreign demand – the June manufacturing PMIs suggest that global growth continued to cool last month," CapEco says. The consultancy is more certain that base effects were responsible for the weak imports data, though acknowledges that the fall in commodity prices probably played a role. Nevertheless, the decline adds to broader evidence that China’s economy lost momentum last month, CapEco says. The consultancy says that headwinds to trade are likely to intensify in the coming quarters, but it doesn't see global growth bottoming-out until next year. "And while the truce reached between Trump and Xi at the G20 late last month removes the immediate threat of further US tariffs, our base case remains that trade talks will break down again before long," adding that "meanwhile, a renewed slowdown in domestic demand looks set to weigh on import volumes for the remainder of the year."

* CHINA STIMULUS: The head of the Chinese Academy of Fiscal Sciences, a key think tank under the Ministry of Commerce, stated that China will not fire another giant stimulus programme comparable to that seen during the 2008 crisis (which helped lead to overcapacity and inefficiencies in the manufacturing sector), to insulate against the trade war with the US. Instead, China will rely on tax cuts and budget reform.

* TURKEY: Turkey has begun taking deliveries of the Russian S-400 missile system, likely setting up more tensions between the nation and the US, and potentially triggering US sanctions against a NATO ally. Later, US acting Defence Secretary Esper said he was aware of Turkey taking delivery of the Russian S-400 missile system, adding he will speak to his Turkish counterpart; he also said that the US position on the F-35 programme had not changed.

* IRAN: US has decided not to impose sanctions on Iran Foreign Minister Zarif for now, according to sources. Meanwhile, US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US condemns Iran's attempt to harass the UK vessel near Strait of Hormuz, and he commended the Royal Navy for ensuring freedom of navigation, adding that the US will continue working with allies to ensure Iran does not disrupt maritime security and global commerce.

* EUROZONE JUNE INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION: A solid headline, at +0.9% M/M in May, topping the Street's view for +0.2%; the Y/Y rate lifted a touch to -0.5% from -0.4%, above the consensus -1.5%. Pantheon Macroeconomics reminds us that the headline excludes construction, which was a hefty drag on German industrial production data for the month, released earlier in the week. Nevertheless, Pantheon says, and in any case, it argues that the details are solid across the board: output in Germany, France, Spain and Italy, was higher; while in the bloc's smaller economies, strong growth was seen in Ireland and the Netherlands, offsetting weakness in Portugal and Finland. "In total, these headlines ease the pressure somewhat on the otherwise dire Q2 GDP forecasts, but the economy isn’t out of the woods," the consultancy writes, "surveys suggest production should be falling by as much as 2% Y/Y, pointing to downside risks in the coming months." Pantheon does not hold much optimism for the June report, which it says "will be a stinker."

* BOE: BoE's Vlieghe said he sees the Bank Rate lowered to close to 0% in the event of a no-deal Brexit and it is highly uncertain when it would rise again. Vlieghe said the bank rate (in the event that a Brexit deal is completed) could reach 1.0% in 1 year, 1.25% in 2 years and 1.75% in 3 years.

* WGC MID-YEAR REPORT: The World Gold Council's 2019 mid-year outlook sees financial market uncertainty and an accommodative monetary policy stance from major central banks as likely to support gold investment demand. It adds that price momentum and positioning might fuel rallies and create pullbacks, with investors continuously reassessing their expectations based on incoming information. The WGC also says that weaker economic growth might soften consumer demand for gold in the near term, however, structural economic reforms in India and China is still likely to provide support in the long-term.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 127-03+. A lacklustre session saw Treasury yields come in by around a basis point or so. Fed speak (Evans, Kashkari, Brainard) was generally positive for the complex given the dovish rhetoric. The yield curve steepened slightly. Major curve spreads were mixed, but relatively unchanged.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.01 HIGHER AT USD 62.21; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 0.20 HIGHER AT USD 66.72: We continue to linger near six-week highs, with WTI holding above USD 60.00, and Brent holding above USD 66.00. Geopolitical tensions (namely, Iran) and weather conditions in the Gulf of Mexico (which has shuttered 59% of crude production in the GoM, taking around 1mln barrels BPD of production offline) are supporting. Additionally, the refinery rich region of Louisiana has been declared a state of emergency. "With Barry now expected to top out as a strong tropical storm, high winds are less of an issue, but this was always going to be a more serious rain event with two feet possible in some locations over a three-day span, and with rivers already nearly full, flooding is the major risk." Citi says. Meanwhile, the IEA report completed the monthly crude reports from the big three agencies. The IEA notes a 0.5mln BPD surplus in Q2 (it had previously seen a 0.5mln BPD deficit). This echoed the EIA STEO report from earlier in the week, and Citi says it has drawn a similar response from forecasters, who are now pencilling in stronger second half growth in order to limit the impact on their demand outlook for the year. "Demand growth can be volatile in this way, with 'missing' offtake from one period showing up later, but it also represents a downside risk to the forecast if that expected 2H surge in demand fails to make an appearance," the bank writes. Elsewhere, the IEA also highlighted the declining call on OPEC, particularly into Q1 of 2020, when seasonal demand is soft. This week, Baker Hughes reported oil rigs -4 at 784, natgas rigs -2 at 172, total rigs -5 at 958.

* S&P 500 +0.5% at 3014, NASDAQ-100 +0.6% at 7943, DOW +0.9% at 27331. SECTORS: Communication +0.7%, consumer discretionary +1.1%, consumer staples +0.3%, energy +0.4%, financials +0.6%, health care -1.2%, industrials +1.8%, IT +0.8%, materials +1.0%, telecoms +0.6%, utilities -0.6%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: PC, as well as PC component makers, including Apple (AAPL), HP Inc (HPQ), Dell Technologies (DELL) and the semiconductor sector were supported by strong global PC shipment data from Gartner. Altria (MO) and Philip Morris (PM) moved higher on the news that a measure to overturn San Francisco’s recent ban on e cigarette sales has qualified for the November 2019 election. Facebook (FB) shares were under pressure after US President Trump spoke negatively on Libra and cryptocurrencies in general. Pharmaceutical and Biotech names were also under pressure on Friday, with Pfizer (PFE), Merck & Co. (MRK), Eli Lilly (LLY) and Amgen (AMGN) continuing losses after the Trump administration’s decision on Thursday to pull a bill that eliminates rebates from government drug plans. Compounding the sectors woes were medical instrument supplier Illumina (ILMN), which fell after the reporting abysmal revenue and revised down guidance, and Johnson and Johnson (JNJ), who sunk on reports it faces a criminal probe about what it knew about the cancer risks regarding baby talcum powder, though the company later denied the report. Anadarko (APC) shares rose on the news its stakeholders would vote on 8th August on the company's proposed USD 38bln sale to Occidental Petroleum (OXY), whose shares were also supported. Raytheon (RTN) shares were under pressure after China warned of sanctions on companies involved in the US’ USD 2bln arms sale to Taiwan. Spirit Airlines (SAVE) fell after the co. issued disappointing Q2 forecasts. Ford (F) jumped higher after Volkswagen injected USD 2.6bln into the co.’s self-driving unit. Snap Inc (SNAP) popped higher pre-market on an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. Milacron Holdings Corp (MCRN) caught a bit pre-market on the news the co.’s USD 2bln sale to Hillenbrand Inc (HI), who subsequently sunk. AB InBev (BUD) is now not pursuing Bud Asia IPO due to market conditions. Notable stocks benefitting from positive broker moves; Morgan Stanley (MS), Snap (SNAP) and GrubHub (GRUB) all upgraded at Goldman Sachs.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: USD: The Dollar continues to fade from post-NFP highs that extended to 97.593 on Tuesday, albeit partly if not largely on the back of weakness elsewhere. However, the pivot or pivotal moment came just 24 hours later with the midweek semi-annual testimony from Fed Chair Powell and his significantly downgraded assessment of the inflation outlook. To recap, there is now a risk that prices will remain weak more persistently rather than due to transitory factors, and this alongside a reiteration of the pledge to take the necessary policy action to ensure that economic growth remains solid effectively sets the stage for ease at the July FOMC. The question is will it be 25 or 50 bp, and subsequent firmer than expected CPI and PPI prints suggest the former, though market pricing is still split (80/20). In response, the DXY is just holding onto the 97.000 handle, but off worst levels (96.792) and from a technical perspective above the 200 DMA.

* CHF, JPY: The traditional safe-havens are both ending the week on a high with the Franc actually probing fresh peaks vs the Buck and Euro circa 0.9845 and 1.1075 respectively, while the Yen is retesting 108.00 against the Greenback amidst rumbling if not rising tensions across the global (trade, arms and geopolitical).

* CAD: Off best levels, but still on track to top the G10 ranks and not far from a new 2019 best vs its US counterpart. Firmer crude prices have been supportive, but the Loonie really started to appreciate on reflection after the BoC policy meeting that maintained a neutral stance with data-dependency, albeit tinged or tilted more cautiously given ongoing/heightened risks to the base-line scenario for Canadian growth and inflation. Usd/Cad currently around 1.3045 within 1.3018-1.3143 parameters.

* AUD, NZD: The Antipodean Dollars have endured some volatile price action over the course of the week, and especially the Kiwi that was hit hard on Wednesday when stops were tripped and potentially exacerbated or initiated by an erroneous trade. However, Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd have recovered well to trade nearer the tops than bottoms of 0.7009-0.6911 and 0.6691-0.6569 respective ranges, while the Aud/Nzd cross is around 1.475 between 1.0538-1.0447 bounds as NZ manufacturing PMI rebounded from perilously close to 50 vs Aussie business and consumer confidence deteriorating further. Ahead, RBA minutes may underline a wait-and-see stance after back-to-back OCR cuts, while NZ Q2 CPI will be a major input for the RBNZ.

* GBP: Monthly UK GDP data for May was better than feared following last week’s trio of dismal PMIs (albeit for June), but the Pound has made most ground thanks to relative Dollar weakness and short covering given ongoing political and Brexit uncertainty. Cable is ‘comfortably’ above 1.2500 within 1.2571-1.2441 confines.

* EUR, SEK, NOK: The single currency looks set to be Friday’s major laggard as speculation mounts about the ECB going all in on July 25 with a rate cut and fresh round of QE possibly augmented by other stimulus measures. Hence, an even more dovish near term outlook compared to the Fed, while divergence from the Riksbank and Norges Bank could become more apparent as minutes from the former retained guidance for another repo hike late this year or early next, and the latter is still signalling further tightening in September 2019. Eur/Usd is now near 1.1245 vs 1.1195 at worst and 1.1285 at best, Eur/Sek just off a 10.5400 base vs 10.6380+ at one stage and Eur/Nok hugging the base of a 9.6055-9.7170 range.

* EM: More thrills and spills across the region amidst the general risk trends and Usd rise and fall noted above. However, the Lira has been a notable underperformer on multi-negative/bearish factors starting with the CBRT head’s sacking last weekend, then more moves to tap Central Bank reserves and culminating in ramped tensions between Turkey and the US/EU over Russia’s S-400 missiles and drilling off Cyprus that appear likely to trigger more and stricter sanctions. Usd/Try hit 5.7930 before easing back a bit in contrast to Usd/Zar and Usd/Brl down to 13.8600 and 3.7355 respectively at their lows on reports of more aid for Eskom and the SARB Governor getting 5 years more in office, while Brazil’s Pension Reform bill is progressing through the Lower House via various amendments, but should be presented to the Senate in time for a vote before the recess.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 12th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

Of note for PC & component manufacturers, including Apple (AAPL), Dell Technologies (DELL), HP (HPQ), Micron Technologies (MU) etc; global PC shipments grew 1.5% in Q2 2019, following two quarters of decline, according to preliminary results from Gartner. Shipments totalled 63mln units in the Q2 2019, an increase from the 62mln units shipped in Q2 2018.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has reportedly ended development of its widely rumoured augmented reality glasses project, reported DigiTimes. In other news, Apple have restored a software application to the App Store allowing parents to control their children's iPhone usage, after it was previously removed in February.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – The executive in charge of the 737 MAX aircraft program is to retire. Elsewhere, US Attorney General William Barr has recursed himself from overseeing the probe into Boeing’s 737 MAX because his former law firm is representing Boeing.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) will terminate Windows 7 Internet Games services by 2020, the co. announced in a blog post.
  • Nike (NKE) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) is to set go ahead with an investment into a factory in Arizona. The expansion is expected to create 500 permanent jobs.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) employees fear that the company is spying on their social media accounts, reported Business Insider, after an employee was fired earlier in the week for sharing confidential information on a Walmart-focused subreddit earlier in the week.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – YouTube’s Chief Product Officer Mohan said that the online video streaming website is working to update its abuse policy in the near future to address "creator-on-creator harassment" reported the Verge.
  • Amgen Inc. (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology), Novartis (NVS) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Banner Alzheimer's Institute have announced a decision end an investigation into the BACE1 inhibitor CNP520 in two Phase 2/3 studies in the Alzheimer's Prevention Initiative Generation Program, after an assessment of the data during a review revealed a worsening in some cases of cognitive function.
  • Baidu (BIDU) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) had its price target lowered to USD 145 from USD 160 at Barclays; analyst Gregory Zhao commented that the problem facing Baidu is how to square a slowdown in ads revenue growth but a ramping-up of the high-tech units' monetization, which could take up to three years. Zhao remains positive on Baidu's mid-long term outlook, but thinks investors' focus will remain on its ads business.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has reportedly closed a deal with Ubisoft (UBSFY) as the co. looks to bring well-known games to bolster its Oculus VR headset business. Elsewhere, US President Trump tweeted "I am not a fan of Bitcoin (BTC) and other Cryptocurrencies, which are not money, and whose value is highly volatile and based on thin air. Unregulated Crypto Assets can facilitate unlawful behaviour, including drug trade and other illegal activity. Similarly, Facebook Libra's "virtual currency" will have little standing or dependability. If Facebook and other companies want to become a bank, they must seek a new Banking Charter and become subject to all Banking Regulations, just like other Banks, both National and International. We have only one real currency in the USA, and it is stronger than ever, both dependable and reliable. It is by far the most dominant currency anywhere in the World, and it will always stay that way. It is called the United States Dollar!"
  • Illumina Inc (ILMN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) (USD) reports Q2 revenue 0.835mln (exp. 0.888), expects revenue to grow 6% this fiscal year, below the prior estimate of 13-14%.
  • Lululemon (LULU) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) had its price target raised to USD 238 from USD 209 at Stifel; analyst Jim Duffy noted the planned 2020 market expansion of lululemon practice, a fee-based membership program that provides benefits to enrolled members, will not only increase revenue but the co. will be better able to serve its most valuable and engaged guests.
  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) will stop selling newspapers including the NYT, WSJ etc. from 1 September due to a problem with lost and stolen goods. Reportedly, customers take them off of the shelf and use them without paying out of habit. Elsewhere, Starbucks had its PT raised to USD 95 from USD 82 at Oppenheimer; analyst Brian Bittner commented that his new analysis highlights a "unique opportunity" for the Street's earnings outlook to improve on a better-than-expected path for the co.’s margins.
  • Tesla (TESLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is to ask Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) for help in a lawsuit; the electric automaker is claiming that a previous employee took trade secrets to XMotors.ai, which is the U.S. research business of Guangzhou-based Xpeng. Apple has previously made similar claims about employees who have moved to the Chinese company. Elsewhere, a Tesla Semi prototype was seen on a California highway with some speculating that there wasn’t a driver at the wheel.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is set to launch a new Echo speaker with premium sounds in 2020m, as the co. looks to compete with high-end speaker makers such as Sonos.

S&P 500

  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco), Philip Morris International (PM) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) – A measure to overturn San Francisco’s recent ban on e cigarette sales has qualified for the November 2019 election, reported the Associated Press. Elsewhere, Altria Group was upgraded to a Buy from Neutral at Goldman Sachs; analyst Judy Hong noted that valuations in tobacco names are currently at a 10-year trough despite what Hong called a "more accommodating” macro backdrop for Consumer Staples (the economy in its late cycle stage and lower yields).
  • Anadarko Petroleum Corp (APC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) stakeholders will vote on 8 August on the company's proposed USD 38bln sale to Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production).
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) announced intentions to sell its Danish unit Kelsen Group to Belgian holding company CTH Invest (a Ferrero affiliate) for USD 300mln. "The sale of Kelsen Group supports our strategy to focus on North America where we have iconic brands and strong market positions, while reducing debt," Campbell CEO Clouse said.
  • Colgate-Palmolive (CL) (Consumer Staples/Household Products) announced plans on Thursday to buy the skin care unit of Laboratoires Filorga Cosmétiques for EUR 1.5bln, "This acquisition also provides Colgate entry into the fast-growing and sizeable travel retail channel, particularly in Asia," CEO Wallace said. The co. will finance the transaction with a combination of debt and cash and the deal is not expected to have any impact on diluted EPS for 2019.
  • Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) driverless car partner Argo AI is set to receive an investment from Volkswagen (VWAGY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers), valuing it at roughly USD 7bln. The German automaker will also integrate its Audi (AUDVF) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) Autonomous Intelligent Driving division into Argo. 
  • General Dynamics (GD) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense), Raytheon Co. (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – China have threatened to sanction companies involved in the US’s USD 2bln arms sale to Taiwan, which includes 108 Abrams tanks (designed by General Dynamics) and around 250 Stinger surface-to-air missiles (designed by General Dynamics and manufactured by Raytheon).
  • Morgan Stanley (MS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral at Citi.

OTHER

  • Daimler (DAI GY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) – Co’s Q2 EBIT is significantly below market expectations; group EBIT EUR -1.6bln vs. Prev. EUR +2.6bln, Mercedes-Benz cars EUR -0.7bln vs. prev. EUR +1.9bln, Daimler trucks EUR +0.7bln vs. Prev. EUR +0.5bln, Mercedes-Benz vans EUR -2.0bln vs. Prev. EUR +0.2bln. The co. state that EBIT was impacted by a reassessment made today in connection with ongoing governmental & court proceedings, lead to increased expenditures of EUR 1.6bln.
  • Hillenbrand (HL) (Industrials/Machinery) is to acquire Milacron (MCRN) (Industrials/Machinery) in a cash and stock deal valuing the latter at roughly USD 2bln.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%] are little changed from their opening levels, with Stoxx price action initially dictated by Daimler’s profit warning
  • Dollar is still somewhat softer to the benefit of G10 counterparts and bonds continue to slump
  • US decided not to impose sanctions on Iran Foreign Minister Zarif for now, according to sources.
  • US President Trump has declared a state of emergency in Louisiana and the NHC believe Barry may become a hurricane tonight/Saturday morning
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US PPI, Baker Hughes Rig Count, Norges Bank’s Nicolaisen, Fed’s Evans

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were somewhat cautious as the region awaited the latest Chinese trade data and following a mixed performance on Wall St. where markets were tentative amid a plethora of Fed speakers, although the DJIA outperformed and rose above the previously uncharted 27K level. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was dragged lower by most mining-related sectors but with downside stemmed by resilience in the largest-weighted financials industry and strength in energy after news Santos is considering a takeover of rival Oil Search, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) mirrored an indecisive currency with index giant Fast Retailing the outperformer after it posted 9-month profit growth. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were choppy ahead of the Chinese trade figures and after PBoC inaction resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln, although Chinese press reports continued to suggest potential for lower rates in China and more room for easing. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the weakness of their counterparts in US where the curve bear steepened in the aftermath of firmer than expected CPI data, while the tentative risk tone and BoJ presence for JPY 940bln of JGBs also failed to provide support for prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln vs. Prev. drain CNY 340bln last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8662 (Prev. 6.8677)

PBoC Offical says they will further reduce real interest rates for small firms, and China will take macro-prudential measures when necessary to keep the Yuan basically stable. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q2) Q/Q -3.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 3.8%) Singapore GDP (Q2) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.2%)

Chinese Trade Balance USD* Jun 50.98B vs. Exp. 44.65B (Prev. 41.66B)

- Chinese Imports YY* Jun -7.3% vs. Exp. -4.5% (Prev. -8.5%)

- Chinese Exports YY* Jun -1.3% vs. Exp. -2.0% (Prev. 1.1%)

US

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said downside risks and soft inflation argue for easing monetary policy, while she added that judgement on appropriate path of rates will depend on evolution of data and risks. Furthermore, Brainard said the economy is expanding solidly and financials markets are supportive of growth, but also noted capital spending is lacklustre and business sentiment is soft. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated that he supports a rate cut to re-anchor inflation expectations, while he suggested that a 25bps cut would not be enough of a shock and that 50bps cut is needed. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he is dropping efforts to include the citizenship question on the consensus but is not backing down on citizenship data efforts and said it is essential to have a clear breakdown of the number of citizens as well as non-citizens, while he is issuing an executive order to access citizenship records. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said she sees the need to act on debt ceiling and budget caps before the August break. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Minister Yi urges the US 'not to play with fire' on the question of Taiwan. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

BoE's Vlieghe says he sees the Bank Rate lowered to close to 0% in the event of a no-deal Brexit and it is highly uncertain when it would rise again

- Bank rate (in the event that a Brexit deal is completed) could reach 1% in 1 year, 1.25% in 2 years and 1.75% in 3 years

- would not need much of a hit on demand to justify cutting rates to zero, and it is more likely than not that rates would reach the lower bound following a no-deal Brexit; it is possible that the Bank may meed to increase rates, if inflation expectations become un-anchored by a no-deal Brexit

 

Initial interviews for the next Bank of England governor have been carried out, leaving the appointment process in limbo until a new chancellor is named. (Times)

Italian Economy Minister Tria says that Italy are ready to work with France and Spain to change European fiscal rules. (Newswires)

EU Industrial Production MM May 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.5%, Rev. -0.4%)

- EU Industrial Production YY May -0.5% vs. Exp. -1.6% (Prev. -0.4%)

GEOPOLITICS

US decided not to impose sanctions on Iran Foreign Minister Zarif for now, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US condemns Iran's attempt to harass the UK vessel near Strait of Hormuz, while it commends the Royal Navy for ensuring freedom of navigation and will continue working with allies to ensure Iran does not disrupt maritime security and global commerce. (Twitter)

Turkish Defense Ministry says that the first parts for the S-400 will be delivered to Ankara today. (Newswires)

Grace 1's cargo has been confirmed as 2.1mln barrels of light crude oil., according to Gibraltar's Chief Minister; subsequently, Iran Cleric Sedighi says that Britain will be 'slapped in the face' for 'daring' to capture an Iranian oil tanker (Newswires)

EQUITIES

 

Major European Indices are little changed, and haven’t substantially deviated from their mildly positive opening levels [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%]. The Dax (U/C) was waylaid in pre-market trade where the future was initially higher by around 0.4%, however, following Daimler (-1.3) stating that their Q2 EBIT is to be significantly below expectations, at EUR -1.6bln vs. Prev. EUR +2.6bln, futures then indicated a lower open for the bourse. The profit warning from Daimler did impact the opening calls and initial cash levels for its major counterparts though the likes of Volkswagen (1.0%) and BMW (U/C) have largely recovered. Other notable movers this morning include, Ab InBev (-2.0%) who are subdued following a sources report that Budweiser’s Hong Kong unit will not price its IPO before Friday; follows on from reports earlier in the week that the pricing is to be at the lower end of the indicative range. A beat on EBIT Exp. has pushed EMS-Chemie (+6.0%) to the top of the Stoxx 600, with Swatch (+3.6%) just below this after being upgraded to buy at Goldman Sachs. Finally, and perhaps this mornings largest mover is Thomas Cook (-44.0%) after the Co. announced they are seeking a GBP 750mln injection from the Fosun Group, which would give the group a controlling stake in the tour operator and a minority interest within the airline its self; with the majority of the Co’s GBP 1.4bln in debt to be written off and converted into shares diluting the value for existing shareholders, hence the overwhelmingly negative reaction to this news.

FX

 

AUD/NZD/CAD/CHF - The non-US Dollars continue to prosper at the expense of their major counterpart, with the Aussie back on the 0.7000 handle, albeit just, Kiwi inching closer towards 0.6700 and Loonie not far from 1.3000 where big barriers reside having breached last week’s pre-NFP and prior 2019 peak of 1.3038. Usd/Cad continues to decline on Fed/BoC policy divergence as the former seems almost certain to deliver an insurance cut at the end of the month, while the latter is sticking to a neutral stance. Similarly, Aud/Usd is realigning after the RBA’s consecutive 25 bp OCR reduction and shift to wait-and-see mode, while Nzd/Usd appears to be biding time ahead of next week’s Q2 NZ inflation data that will be a key driver for the RBNZ. Elsewhere, the Franc is also gaining further ground vs the Buck after surpassing 0.9900, but also outperforming against the Euro with the cross eyeing 1.1100 following a break below 1.1150.

GBP/JPY/EUR/SEK/NOK - All moderately firmer, as Cable holds above 1.2500 and the Yen pivots 108.50 in close proximity to decent expiry options (1.2 bn between 108.50-40). However, the Pound has drifted back down from recovery highs closer to 1.2600 amidst dovish comments from BoE’s Vlieghe in the event of a no deal Brexit when he believes rates could be set near zero, while Usd/Jpy remains reluctant to venture too far under 108.00. By the same token, the single currency is still confined below 1.1300 amidst an array of expiries spanning 1.1250 (1 bn), 1.1270-75 (1.1 bn) and the big figure (1.1 bn), with no real boost from better than expected Eurozone ip data even though EGB yields have rebounded further in response. Hence, Eur/Sek has now slipped through 10.5500 and Eur/Nok is straddling 9.6100, though the Swedish Krona has been underpinned to an extent by Riksbank minutes retaining guidance for a repo hike around the turn of the year and its Norwegian neighbour is underpinned by firm oil prices.

EM - Although the Greenback is off lows and the DXY is probing 97.000+ levels again, the latest leg up in Usd/Try is mainly due to heightened US/EU-Turkey angst and anticipation that tougher sanctions are on the way. Note also, the Lira’s lurch towards 5.7150 at one stage also came amidst reports that the first batch of S-400 missile system components have arrived from Russia.

Option Expiries of Note:

- EUR/USD: 1.1200-10 (2BLN), 1.1215-20 (500M), 1.1250 (1BLN), 1.1270-75 (1.1BLN), 1.1300 (1.1BLN), 1.1325 (340M), 1.1350 (300M)

- GBP/USD: 1.2580 (600M)

- USD/CAD: 1.3000 (460M), 1.3050 (1BLN), 1.3100 (2.1BLN)

- USD/JPY: 107.50 (1.3BLN) , 107.70 (500M), 108.00 (566M), 108.20-25 (500M), 108.40-50 (1.2BLN), 109.00 (1.4BLN)

 

Riksbank Minutes:

- The board members supported the picture of the economic outlook and inflation prospects described in the draft Monetary Policy Report.

- Floden says he does not believe than the Krona depreciation helps the Bank to stabilize inflation around its long term target

- Jansson says the problems and risks relating to inflationary pressures in Sweden and developments abroad mean than may fear that the probability currently embedded in out repo-rate path of a rate increase as early as October

- It was noted that participants on the financial markets seem to be expecting significantly worse economic development in the period ahead and hence further monetary policy stimuli.

 

FIXED INCOME 

Although the omens were good via French and Italian outturns, the pan Eurozone ip data beat seemed to spark the latest shank down in bonds, as Bunds slumped to a new 171.25 Eurex low having marginally extended recovery gains to 6 ticks on the day at 171.88 in advance, with the heavy selling spreading across the bloc and beyond. Indeed, Gilts have been dragged down from 130.54 (+18 ticks) towards the early Liffe trough (130.14) and the US Treasury complex is softer/curve steeper ahead of US PPI and another Fed speaker to close out a busy week, highlighted by Powell’s semi-annual testimony that removed residual doubt about a July FOMC ease, albeit with the size still up for some debate.

COMMODITIES

 

WTI and Brent are in positive territory and adding to the weeks gains of around USD 4.0/bbl on the back of significant drawdowns in weekly crude data, ongoing geopolitical tensions including the seizure of Iran’s Grace 1 which is carrying 2.1mln/bbl of light crude and the Gulf of Mexico storm. On the latter, the NHC have most recently stated that Storm Barry may become a hurricane by Friday night or early Saturday, in terms of production, reports are indicating that around 53% of the Gulf’s production is shut; the concern/focus may switch more towards refineries as the storm approaches land with Louisiana representing 20% of the US’ refinery capacity. This morning saw the release of the final monthly oil market report, where the IEA maintained their 2019 global oil demand growth estimate at 1.2mln BPD; for reference, earlier in the week OPEC also maintained their forecast at 1.14mln BPD while EIA cut theirs to 1.07mln BPD.

Gold (+0.1%) Is modestly firmer this morning benefiting from the dollars ongoing weakness. However, the metal has drifted back towards the USD 1400/oz mark and if this mornings relatively rangebound trade continues is set to finish the week within a few dollars an ounce of where it started; and indeed in a similar area to the last two weeks closing figures. Elsewhere, copper prices have continued to trade sideways post the key Chinese data, which had little impact on the metal.

 

IEA Monthly Report: 2019 global oil demand growth estimate 1.2mln bpd (maintained) and sees 2020 at 1.4mln bpd

- Balances show the potential for oversupply next year, with a 2.1mln bpd expansion of non-OPEC supply, led by the US, versus 2mln bpd in 2019

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: USD still stumped, and bonds bowled over again - 12th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

EQUITIES

Major European Indices are little changed, and haven’t substantially deviated from their mildly positive opening levels [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%]. The Dax (U/C) was waylaid in pre-market trade where the future was initially higher by around 0.4%, however, following Daimler (-1.3) stating that their Q2 EBIT is to be significantly below expectations, at EUR -1.6bln vs. Prev. EUR +2.6bln, futures then indicated a lower open for the bourse. The profit warning from Daimler did impact the opening calls and initial cash levels for its major counterparts though the likes of Volkswagen (1.0%) and BMW (U/C) have largely recovered. Other notable movers this morning include, Ab InBev (-2.0%) who are subdued following a sources report that Budweiser’s Hong Kong unit will not price its IPO before Friday; follows on from reports earlier in the week that the pricing is to be at the lower end of the indicative range. A beat on EBIT Exp. has pushed EMS-Chemie (+6.0%) to the top of the Stoxx 600, with Swatch (+3.6%) just below this after being upgraded to buy at Goldman Sachs. Finally, and perhaps this mornings largest mover is Thomas Cook (-44.0%) after the Co. announced they are seeking a GBP 750mln injection from the Fosun Group, which would give the group a controlling stake in the tour operator and a minority interest within the airline its self; with the majority of the Co’s GBP 1.4bln in debt to be written off and converted into shares diluting the value for existing shareholders, hence the overwhelmingly negative reaction to this news.

FX

AUD/NZD/CAD/CHF - The non-US Dollars continue to prosper at the expense of their major counterpart, with the Aussie back on the 0.7000 handle, albeit just, Kiwi inching closer towards 0.6700 and Loonie not far from 1.3000 where big barriers reside having breached last week’s pre-NFP and prior 2019 peak of 1.3038. Usd/Cad continues to decline on Fed/BoC policy divergence as the former seems almost certain to deliver an insurance cut at the end of the month, while the latter is sticking to a neutral stance. Similarly, Aud/Usd is realigning after the RBA’s consecutive 25 bp OCR reduction and shift to wait-and-see mode, while Nzd/Usd appears to be biding time ahead of next week’s Q2 NZ inflation data that will be a key driver for the RBNZ. Elsewhere, the Franc is also gaining further ground vs the Buck after surpassing 0.9900, but also outperforming against the Euro with the cross eyeing 1.1100 following a break below 1.1150.

GBP/JPY/EUR/SEK/NOK - All moderately firmer, as Cable holds above 1.2500 and the Yen pivots 108.50 in close proximity to decent expiry options (1.2 bn between 108.50-40). However, the Pound has drifted back down from recovery highs closer to 1.2600 amidst dovish comments from BoE’s Vlieghe in the event of a no deal Brexit when he believes rates could be set near zero, while Usd/Jpy remains reluctant to venture too far under 108.00. By the same token, the single currency is still confined below 1.1300 amidst an array of expiries spanning 1.1250 (1 bn), 1.1270-75 (1.1 bn) and the big figure (1.1 bn), with no real boost from better than expected Eurozone ip data even though EGB yields have rebounded further in response. Hence, Eur/Sek has now slipped through 10.5500 and Eur/Nok is straddling 9.6100, though the Swedish Krona has been underpinned to an extent by Riksbank minutes retaining guidance for a repo hike around the turn of the year and its Norwegian neighbour is underpinned by firm oil prices.

EM - Although the Greenback is off lows and the DXY is probing 97.000+ levels again, the latest leg up in Usd/Try is mainly due to heightened US/EU-Turkey angst and anticipation that tougher sanctions are on the way. Note also, the Lira’s lurch towards 5.7150 at one stage also came amidst reports that the first batch of S-400 missile system components have arrived from Russia.

FIXED INCOME

Although the omens were good via French and Italian outturns, the pan Eurozone ip data beat seemed to spark the latest shank down in bonds, as Bunds slumped to a new 171.25 Eurex low having marginally extended recovery gains to 6 ticks on the day at 171.88 in advance, with the heavy selling spreading across the bloc and beyond. Indeed, Gilts have been dragged down from 130.54 (+18 ticks) towards the early Liffe trough (130.14) and the US Treasury complex is softer/curve steeper ahead of US PPI and another Fed speaker to close out a busy week, highlighted by Powell’s semi-annual testimony that removed residual doubt about a July FOMC ease, albeit with the size still up for some debate.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are in positive territory and adding to the weeks gains of around USD 4.0/bbl on the back of significant drawdowns in weekly crude data, ongoing geopolitical tensions including the seizure of Iran’s Grace 1 which is carrying 2.1mln/bbl of light crude and the Gulf of Mexico storm. On the latter, the NHC have most recently stated that Storm Barry may become a hurricane by Friday night or early Saturday, in terms of production, reports are indicating that around 53% of the Gulf’s production is shut; the concern/focus may switch more towards refineries as the storm approaches land with Louisiana representing 20% of the US’ refinery capacity. This morning saw the release of the final monthly oil market report, where the IEA maintained their 2019 global oil demand growth estimate at 1.2mln BPD; for reference, earlier in the week OPEC also maintained their forecast at 1.14mln BPD while EIA cut theirs to 1.07mln BPD.

Gold (+0.1%) Is modestly firmer this morning benefiting from the dollars ongoing weakness. However, the metal has drifted back towards the USD 1400/oz mark and if this mornings relatively rangebound trade continues is set to finish the week within a few dollars an ounce of where it started; and indeed in a similar area to the last two weeks closing figures. Elsewhere, copper prices have continued to trade sideways post the key Chinese data, which had little impact on the metal.

content:

  • That will lower the requirement for OPEC crude, with the call on OPEC plunging to 28mln bpd in Q1 2020. OPEC has not produced at such a low level since Q3 2003

subject: Chinese Imports CNY* Jun -0.4% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 2.5%)
Chinese Exports CNY* Jun 6.1% vs. Exp. 6.9% (Prev. 7.7%)
Chinese Trade Balance CNY* Jun 345.18B  vs. Exp. 278.50B (Prev. 279.12B)
analysis_details: Exports were hit, turning negative in June, as the US ramped up tariffs on China in May, against the backdrop of cooling global demand. Imports were also softer, amid a renewed domestic slowdown. Capital Economics said the export data was negative partly due to a stronger base for comparison, but it also notes that shipments fell in seasonally adjusted M/M terms. "The latest US tariff hike, implemented in the middle of May, probably contributed to this drop, alongside a broader slowdown in foreign demand – the June manufacturing PMIs suggest that global growth continued to cool last month," CapEco says. The consultancy is more certain that base effects were responsible for the weak imports data, though acknowledges that the fall in commodity prices probably played a role. Nevertheless, the decline adds to broader evidence that China’s economy lost momentum last month, CapEco says. The consultancy says that headwinds to trade are likely to intensify in the coming quarters. but it doesn't see global growth bottoming-out until next year. "And while the truce reached between Trump and Xi at the G20 late last month removes the immediate threat of further US tariffs, our base case remains that trade talks will break down again before long," adding that "meanwhile, a renewed slowdown in domestic demand looks set to weigh on import volumes for the remainder of the year."

Similarly, the 3 month strip has recovered after dipping below par to stand flat-1.5 ticks ahead awaiting a speech from BoE’s Vlieghe at the top of the hour.

Riksbank Minutes: The board members supported the picture of the economic outlook and inflation prospects described in the draft Monetary Policy Report.
content:
• economic development both in Sweden and abroad has been largely in line with the Riksbank’s forecasts and that new information since the monetary policy meeting in April has not led to any major revisions of the forecasts overall
  • International risks are difficult to quantify in a forecast, but if they materialise, prospects may also deteriorate for the Swedish economy. It is therefore important that monetary policy proceeds cautiously
  • It was noted that participants on the financial markets seem to be expecting significantly worse economic development in the period ahead and hence further monetary policy stimuli.
  • Floden says he does not believe than the Krona depreciation helps the Bank to stabilize inflation around its long term target
  • Some also emphasised that large and unexpected fluctuations in the exchange rate make it more difficult to stabilise inflation around the target.
  • Jansson says the problems and risks relating to inflationary pressures in Sweden and developments abroad mean than may fear that the probability currently embedded in out repo-rate path of a rate increase as early as October

content:

  • Asian equity markets were somewhat cautious as the region awaited the latest Chinese trade data and following a mixed performance on Wall St
  • Senior US administration officials agreed that China violated sanctions by importing Iranian oil last month and are now mulling secondary sanctions
  • The greenback was slightly softer overnight as the momentum from the prior day’s firmer than expected US CPI petered out
  • US Gulf of Mexico crude oil production has been cut by 53% (1mln BPD) due to Storm Barry according to the US government
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Chinese trade, Riksbank minutes, IEA monthly report, Eurozone IP, US PPI, Baker Hughes Rig Count, BoE’s Vlieghe, Norges Bank’s Nicolaisen, Fed’s Evans

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were somewhat cautious as the region awaited the latest Chinese trade data and following a mixed performance on Wall St. where markets were tentative amid a plethora of Fed speakers, although the DJIA outperformed and rose above the previously uncharted 27K level. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was dragged lower by most mining-related sectors but with downside stemmed by resilience in the largest-weighted financials industry and strength in energy after news Santos is considering a takeover of rival Oil Search, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) mirrored an indecisive currency with index giant Fast Retailing the outperformer after it posted 9-month profit growth. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were choppy ahead of the Chinese trade figures and after PBoC inaction resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln, although Chinese press reports continued to suggest potential for lower rates in China and more room for easing. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the weakness of their counterparts in US where the curve bear steepened in the aftermath of firmer than expected CPI data, while the tentative risk tone and BoJ presence for JPY 940bln of JGBs also failed to provide support for prices.

Senior US administration officials agreed that China violated sanctions by importing Iranian oil last month and are now mulling secondary sanctions in a move that would strain US-China trade talks. (Politico)

Singapore GDP (Q2) Q/Q -3.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 3.8%) Singapore GDP (Q2) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.2%)

UK/EU

Initial interviews for the next Bank of England governor have been carried out, leaving the appointment process in limbo until a new chancellor is named. (Times)

 

USTR announced initiation of Section 301 investigation into France’s digital services tax. (Newswires)

 

FX

The greenback was slightly softer overnight as the momentum from the prior day’s firmer than expected US CPI data petered out with the DXY now back below the 97.00 level. This benefitted its major counterparts in which EUR/USD broke out of the lull seen during US hours but with advances also contained by nearby large option expiries for today’s New York cut at 1.1250 and 1.1270, while gains in GBP/USD were also limited by the continued political and Brexit-related overhang. Antipodeans remained steadfast against a weaker USD as they awaited the Chinese trade data. Elsewhere, USD/JPY mildly pulled back as a function of a tepid greenback and cautious risk tone, while SGD briefly wobbled following discouraging GDP figures for Q2 which showed the largest quarterly contraction in around 7 years.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were slightly positive overnight but with upside limited by the cautious risk sentiment. As such, WTI crude futures edged mild gains and remained near the prior day’s highs above the USD 60/bbl level following this week’s bullish inventory data and disruption in the Gulf of Mexico where crude output has been cut by more than half amid Tropical Storm Barry which is expected to develop into a hurricane later today. Gold prices saw a mild rebound from support near USD 1400/oz and amid softness in the greenback, while copper proceeded sideways due to the indecisiveness as participants await the latest Chinese trade data.

 

US Gulf of Mexico crude oil production has been cut by 53% (1mln BPD) due to Storm Barry according to the US government, while NHC stated that a hurricane warning was issued for parts of the Louisiana coastline and that Tropical Storm Barry could become a hurricane by later today. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US decided not to impose sanctions on Iran Foreign Minister Zarif for now, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US condemns Iran's attempt to harass the UK vessel near Strait of Hormuz, while it commends the Royal Navy for ensuring freedom of navigation and will continue working with allies to ensure Iran does not disrupt maritime security and global commerce. (Twitter)

 

US

The curve bear-steepened after CPI came in above expectations, diminishing arguments for a 50bps rate cut at the Fed’s July 31st policy meeting, while hawkish Fedspeak from Barkin and Bostic added to the downside, with traders largely having discounted the Powell comments, which were pretty much a copy and paste of Wednesday’s testimony. The 30-year auction was poorly received, tailing by a huge 2.6bps on very soft cover, seeing yields edge higher in its wake. At settlement major curve spreads were wider: 2s30s +41bps, 2s5s +3bps, 2s10s +4bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 14+ ticks lower at 126-31+.

Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said the economy is in a good place but added the Fed must be ready to adjust policy to sustain the expansion and that inflation is below target which could feed into inflation expectations. Williams further commented that arguments for adding accommodation have strengthened over time in which he noted uncertainties around trade and global growth have not improved, while he added that expectations of rate cuts are showing up in easier financial conditions although he sees rates currently as neutral. (Newswires)

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said downside risks and soft inflation argue for easing monetary policy, while she added that judgement on appropriate path of rates will depend on evolution of data and risks. Furthermore, Brainard said the economy is expanding solidly and financials markets are supportive of growth, but also noted capital spending is lacklustre and business sentiment is soft. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawkish) said it is "tricky" to try to use low rates to boost inflation and suggested inflation is running low as well as steady and not a concern for businesses or consumers. Barkin also suggested that it is hard to make the case for both stepping on the gas or stepping on the brakes and that small rate moves are unlikely to do much to move businesses' settled pricing routines, while big rate moves risk providing 4% inflation. However, Barkin later commented that research shows if you are going to do something on rates it is better to do something sooner than later and that he can see the case for an insurance rate cut but that case for a rate cut to re-centre inflation doesn't feel strong enough. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Dove) said he wants to keep an open mind for the July meeting and not front run a rate call, while he added that low readings on inflation are "noisy" and other data suggests the Fed is close to its 2% target not moving away from it. Bostic also commented that the central bank is in a good position right now on jobs and inflation but also noted it is clear risks to the economy have grown compared to the prior year including trade and weak global growth. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated that he supports a rate cut to re-anchor inflation expectations, while he suggested that a 25bps cut would not be enough of a shock and that 50bps cut is needed. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he is dropping efforts to include the citizenship question on the consensus but is not backing down on citizenship data efforts and said it is essential to have a clear breakdown of the number of citizens as well as non-citizens, while he is issuing an executive order to access citizenship records. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said she sees the need to act on debt ceiling and budget caps before the August break. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades somewhat indecisive as participants eye the latest Chinese trade data
content:
Asia equity markets are indecisive as the region awaits the latest Chinese trade data and following a mixed performance on Wall St, where markets were tentative amid a plethora of Fed speakers although the DJIA outperformed and rose above the previously uncharted 27K level. ASX 200 (-0.1%) is dragged lower by most mining-related sectors but with downside stemmed by resilience in the largest-weighted financials industry and strength in energy after news Santos is considering a takeover of rival Oil Search, while Nikkei 225 (Unch.) is also subdued but with losses cushioned by recent currency flows and gains in index giant Fast Retailing which posted 9-month profit growth. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) are choppy ahead of the Chinese trade figures and after PBoC inaction resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 220bln, although Chinese press reports continued to suggest potential for lower rates in China and more room for easing.

In FX markets, the greenback is slightly softer overnight as the momentum from the prior day’s firmer than expected US CPI data petered out with the DXY now back below the 97.00 level. This has benefitted its major counterparts with EUR/USD breaking out of lull seen during US hours but with advances also contained by nearby large option expiries for today’s New York cut at 1.1250 and 1.1270, while gains in GBP/USD are also limited by the continued political and Brexit-related overhang with some even suggesting GBP could plummet to parity against USD if the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal. Antipodeans remain steadfast against a weaker USD as they await the Chinese trade data and CAD is also firmer after the BoC recently refrained from joining in on the dovish bandwagon among the major central banks. Elsewhere, USD/JPY has mildly pulled back as a function of a tepid greenback and cautious risk tone, while SGD briefly wobbled after discouraging GDP figures for Q2 which showed the largest quarterly contraction in around 7 years.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they followed suit to the weakness of their counterparts in US where the curve bear steepened in the aftermath of firmer than expected CPI data, while the subdued risk tone and BoJ presence for JPY 940bln of JGBs also failed to provide support for prices.
